Your name might not carry the same weight everywhere you go, but your gold pouch certainly does.You get a bonus 1,000 starting gold that you can spend as you wish. Your family also gives you an allowance every month of 500g. For campaigns with a faster or slower pace, such as if there are frequent time skips, consider changing how often the allowance comes in.If you are far from home, it can take up to a week for your allowance to arrive. They can only ever be picked up from settlements.See Backgrounds

item.title: Family Man
item.description: You are the primary owner of a house somewhere in the world, usually at least on the tangent of civilization. You lived with either your immediate family, like parents and siblings, or you made a family of your own with a spouse and children.You own a meager house in a specific place, and a handful of family members to come home to after an adventure. Your house is always considered a suitable place to rest in order to cure general afflictions.See Backgrounds

item.title: Background
item.description: Background helps to determine what your character was doing before they got sucked up into an adventure. Other than acquiring the skills necessary to go out into the dangerous world, of course.Backgrounds give starting bonuses or equipment.

item.title: Stealth
item.description:
DEX-based Skill.
Used for Hide and Hide Trail.

item.title: Recharge
item.description: A Recharge ability can only be used once, after which you can use the Recharge Abilities action to restore it.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Recharge.md

item.title: Hands
item.description: DEX-based Skill.Used for Pickpocket, Conceal Item, Pick Lock, and Disable Device.

item.title: Profession
item.description:
WIS or INT-based Skill. For crafting, INT is used, and Trained individuals can use any ability score for Economy uses if doing so has a justification in-character.Professions can be anything used to provide a service or create a product. When you gain a profession, you choose one such specialization, such as Profession (Baker).
Used for Economics and Quiz.

item.title: Survival
item.description: WIS-based Skill.Used for Navigate, Butcher, Live off Land, and Track.

item.title: Coax
item.description:
When an NPC is on the fence or indifferent about a request, and the requester doesn't have anything left to say to sway them, Persuasion can be used to get the target to agree or counter-offer.
The DC varies based on how effective the conversation was before rolling. Requests that align with the target's interests, offerings that make them happy, and moral arguments that resonate with their values will lower the DC, while the opposite will increase it. Passing the check results in the NPC requesting something in return, while rolling significantly higher may cause them to waive any additional requests, or even offer additional assistance that wasn't requested. This action can also be used when the NPC already agreed due to good conversation in-character, in order to try to sweeten the deal if the requester rolls exceptionally well.

item.title: Humanities
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Humanoids and Titans.
Used for Recall Customs, Recognize Figure, and Recall Locale.

item.title: Religion
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Undead.
Used for Divine Lore.

item.title: Planes
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Fiends, Celestials, and Elementals.
Used for Detect Portal.

item.title: Nature
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Plants, Fey, and Beasts.
Used for Identify Natural Phenomenon and Identify Spell.

item.title: Engineering
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Constructs.
Used for Identify Function, Hack, and Identify Structural Quirk.

item.title: Arcana
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Monsters.
Used for Identify Spell and Identify Magic Item.

item.title: Astronomy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Abominations.
Used for Navigation, Identify Spell, and Identify Cosmic Phenomenon.

item.title: Alchemy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Oozes.
Used for Identify Potion, Identify Composition, and Craft alchemical items.

item.title: Intimidation
item.description:
CHA-based Skill, or optionally STR when using displays of might.
Used for Coercion and Demoralize.

item.title: Insight
item.description:
WIS-based Skill, but CHA can be used if it's a social cue.
Used for Detect Dishonesty, Detect Compulsion, and Intuition.

item.title: Deception
item.description:
CHA-based Skill, normally rolled against Insight.
Used to Lie, Disguise, Feint, Create a Distraction, Subtle Message, and Sucker Punch.

item.title: Catch Fall
item.description: When Proficient in Athletics, as an Immediate Action, you can attempt to grab onto something to stop your fall, or to prevent an ally within reach from falling. The DC to do this is 20+the height fallen before the catch. You do not take Fall Damage when successful.

item.title: Brute Force
item.description:
Using Athletics, you can use Brute Force when there are no lockpicks or beasts of burden to handle your problems. The DC to break apart an object is modified by its quality, materials, and size. Substantial failure may cause back problems.
You can also use Athletics to represent bursts of strength that allow you to surpass your normal Carry Weight to shift large objects.

item.title: Climb
item.description: Using Athletics, you can climb surfaces. Spaces you climb through are considered difficult terrain. With Athletics Proficiency, you climb at full Speed.If you have a Climb Speed, you get a +8 bonus and use that speed instead.

item.title: Swim
item.description: Using Athletics, you can swim through liquids. Spaces you swim through are considered difficult terrain. With Athletics Proficiency, you swim at full Speed.If you have a Swim Speed, you get a +8 bonus and use that speed instead.

item.title: Aquatic Combat
item.description: Fighting underwater gives a -4 Circumstance penalty to AC, Reflex, and ACC. Being Trained in Athletics or possessing a Swim Speed removes the penalty.

item.title: Tumble
item.description: If Trained in Acrobatics, you can avoid AoOs from moving through Threatened spaces. Acrobatics is rolled against all threatening creatures’ Reflex saves. The DC of their reflex save is equal to your Acrobatics Roll. If they succeed, your movement Provokes as normal.

item.title: Balance
item.description: Acrobatics can be used to cross slippery surfaces, such as ice or oil slicks, at full speed. Failing the check gives you the Knocked Down condition. It can also be used to traverse or stand on incredibly small and unstable spaces, such as a cliff side or a fallen tree branch.

item.title: Common Prices
item.description: LV 1 Characters start off with 3000g to spend. Higher level characters should get more gold, determined by the DM and as appropriate for the sort of campaign being run.The following are prices of basic equipment. Recall that basic equipment is the lowest quality available. This is budget equipment suitable for militias, thugs, and beginner adventurers.

item.title: The Cost of Living
item.description: Staying alive requires resources and food. The easiest way to obtain and represent these is to spend money. Only accounting for minimum food and necessities, the basic cost to remaining alive is 10g per day.In a town, where sleeping on the streets isn't advised, the cost increases to 30g.The savings from living in the wilderness are made up by the time spent setting up camps and creating one's own resources, as per Live off Land. Characters that do not spend this money must spend additional time collecting enough food to survive. Players should lose this much gold every day to represent the use of supplies. If they are on a particularly long journey where they will not encounter others to sell them supplies, they must spend this money ahead of time to avoid running out of supplies.

item.title: Economics
item.description: Daily income, typically through the use of a skill, like profession, perform or alchemy.All income is based around a formula which calculates a yearly salary (y) based on your skill bonus (x).y=10000+x^2 * 250Salary assumes you work for 5 days a week, 50 weeks a year. Divide this value by 250 to figure our your daily income. The chart below does this formula for you for most expected values. Anything lower than a +0 bonus to the task at hand makes a 5k salary, or 20g daily.This formula assumes a prosperous nation with a lot of economic opportunity and a population with many thousands of people per city. In poorer and less populous regions, consider using the following multiplier for all goods and services.Developing - Multiply all values by .75Poor - Multiply all values by .5

item.title: The Value of Gold
item.description: Estimating the true value of a single unit of currency is difficult to do when considering the possibilities of every setting. However, in order to establish some reference for pricing adventuring gear and items, we have to settle on one - so, for the purposes of the default pricing and earnings, we're going forward with the assumption that the differences between the peasants, tradesmen, and aristocrats is large, but not in such a way that compromises the ability of the peasantry to afford basic items.As a fantasy setting with swords and monsters, there are comparisons to be made to the value of labor in the medieval era. However, in order to avoid mixing the complexities of medieval economics with magic and superheroes to an audience that may not have studied such, the gap between the peasants and aristocrats is reduced, and social mobility is substantially increased. If a more extreme economy is desired, adjust the earnings from Economics and The Cost of Living.Average laborers like farmers can be expected to make ~10-20k gold every year, with the amount increasing with more sophisticated trades such as smiths or merchants.Gold pieces are small coins and are virtually weightless due to the minting process performed by the financial wizards. Another benefit of this minting is that it causes gold pieces to naturally stack into specific values (5, 10, 20, 100, 1000). Someone can easily hold 100g in their pockets, or 1000g in a dedicated pouch. Anything more and they are bursting at the seams and would be better off with a bank, or to switch to alternative methods of payment.Carrying around a bag of 100,000g would be like the real-world equivalent of carrying around a several briefcases full of paper currency. While this may happen for large transactions or when hauling away a dragon's horde, it's usually difficult to avoid drawing attention if you were to do it on the regular.When imagining gold costs, use the following:

item.title: Shield
item.description:
Shields are a subtype Weapon Group. Not all shields can be used as weapons, however.
Shields are primarily used to gain defensive abilities to use as Actions, and most also passively increase your defenses (Mainly AC). Many shields have minimum STR requirements just like Armor, which penalize you in the same manner. Unless otherwise stated, shields are 1-handed.The following are the basic shields.

item.title: At-Will
item.description: An At-Will ability can be used as many times as desired, as long as you spend the appropriate actions (if any).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/At-Will.md

item.title: Limited
item.description: A Limited ability can only be used once, after which you must Long Rest to restore it.If it is a Mana ability, such as a Technique or Spell, you can prepare a different slot with the ability to use it again.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Limited.md

item.title: Persuasion
item.description:
CHA-based Skill.
Used for Coax and Gather Information.

item.title: Bow
item.description:
Bows are a group of Weapons that are 2-handed.
These are curved weapons held at the ends by taut or resistant elastic strings used for firing Ammunition with a drawing motion.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Bow group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Bow.md

item.title: Bludgeon
item.description:
Bludgeons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed. These weapons are meant to beat the snot out of enemies in the most primitive way possible.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Bludgeon group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Bludgeon.md

item.title: Armor
item.description: Armors of varying weights have STR requirements, granting more AC at higher values. You lose 10 Speed and Jump for every point of STR you lack (minimum 5). Armor takes the Armor Equipment Slot. The following are the three most simple and common forms of armor. Light armor consists of hard leathers and gambesons, medium armor includes chain and scales with breastplates, and heavy armor covers every part of the body with a combination of plate, chain, and gambesons.

item.title: Exotic Weapon
item.description: Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into any Weapon Groups, and will list how they differ. They often break the norms of conventional weaponry.

item.title: Natural Weapon
item.description: Natural Weapons are a subtype Weapon Group. All Natural Weapons are also part of another Weapon Group. These weapons are part of a creature's being. Examples include claws, fists, tails, horns, stingers, and tentacles. Most natural weapons are not universal, meaning they are different for each creature that has them and will be noted as such in their stat block. However, they do follow common trends.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Natural Weapon.md

item.title: Ammunition
item.description:
Ammunition is a subtype Weapon Group. All Ammunition is either also part of another Weapon Group, or does not function as a weapon on its own. These represent arrows, bolts, rocks, bullets, darts, or any other weapon that is either part of another weapon's use, or that is meant to be launched by itself in quick succession.
Ammunition can be drawn as an Instant Action. Ammunition and its price and weight represent an unlimited source. You cannot easily "share" or otherwise split Ammunition between allies. You either have the ammunition or you don't - Exceptions can be made in the heat of combat, such as firing back an arrow that just hit a tree next to you.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Ammunition.md

item.title: Trigger
item.description:
Trigger weapons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed. These are weapons with handles that are loaded beforehand and then fire their ammunition with a trigger.
Trigger weapons require an Action-Attack to reload.
Trigger weapons do not add STR to damage.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Trigger group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Trigger.md

item.title: Thrust
item.description:
Thrust weapons are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed. These are blades and spears meant for dedicated thrusts to put enormous pressure at a single point. Often used to outrange and lunge at opponents.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Thrust group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Thrust.md

item.title: Dagger
item.description:
Daggers are a group of Weapons that are 1-handed. These are short, sharp weapons for getting close to enemies and striking weak spots or overwhelming them with angles of attack.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Dagger group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Dagger.md

item.title: Thrown
item.description:
Thrown weapons are a group of Weapons that are almost always 1-handed.
These are weapons designed to be thrown using a swing from the hand or sling. Casters are armored gauntlets with thrown ammunition stored inside, used to draw and throw faster and harder. Many Thrown weapons are also Ammunition.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Thrown group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Thrown.md

item.title: Blade
item.description:
Blades are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed. These weapons are meant for slicing and stabbing, relying on the blade to do the cutting with a mere touch rather than chopping or committed thrusts.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Blade group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Blade.md

item.title: Axe
item.description:
Axes are a group of Weapons that can be 1-handed or 2-handed. These weapons are made to cut or pierce using chopping motions.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Axe group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Axe.md

item.title: Basic Weapon
item.description: Basic Weapons are the default Weapons of a Weapon Group. They represent the effectiveness of common or makeshift weaponry. They have no Upgrade Slots, and come with the fewest amount of Weapon Qualities.

item.title: Equipment Slot
item.description: There is a limit to how much wearable equipment you can use at once. This is represented by Equipment Slots, each of which can hold one piece of equipment of that type. By default, humanoid characters start off with the following Equipment Slots:

item.title: Recall Customs
item.description: Using Humanities, you can recall information about how to conduct yourself with foreign cultures. This can be particularly useful when trying to gain someone's favor, such as royalty. You can also recall information about holidays, festivals and ceremonies.

item.title: Recall Locale
item.description: Using Humanities, you can recall the answer to a specific simple question such as "where can I buy potions?" or "where does the royalty live?" or "where can I hire someone to build something?" These questions can be applied to the town you're in or with a higher DC, something much bigger like a country or continent.

item.title: Recognize Figure
item.description: Using Humanities, you can attach a name to a face, or vice versa. You generally understand aspects of a creature's reputation, their affiliations, and their general capabilities. Exceptionally high rolls might even land you some secrets or gossip related to this creature.

item.title: Disable Device
item.description:
Use Hands to disable a trap or similar mechanism, magical or mundane, as long as it is armed and you have detected its presence. Failure triggers the trap.
If you are Proficient in Hands, you can disable it temporarily or otherwise slightly modify the trap to better suit your needs.

item.title: Hide Trail
item.description: Use Trained Stealth to hide your trail, turning attempts to Track you into an opposed check of their Survival vs your Stealth -5.

item.title: Hide
item.description:
As a Swift Action, Use Stealth to prevent enemies from knowing your exact location. This lasts until you are spotted.
Whenever an enemy has line of sight to you, or you cause some other detectable stimuli, they roll Perception against your Stealth. If you Attack a creature, it gets a +20 bonus on its check. A Ranged Attack grants a +10 bonus.
While moving at half speed or slower and not having taken an action, you get an additional Roll to avoid detection.
You can only take this action while you have Cover or Concealment.

item.title: Track
item.description: Use Survival to follow the path another creature took by looking for footprints, disturbed leaves, markings, etc. The older the tracks, the higher the DC to track them. With ideal conditions, you can follow trails made days or weeks ago.

item.title: Live off Land
item.description: Creatures Proficient in Survival can spend an hour in a wilderness area with suitable sources of food and water to create a Field Ration.In areas that are unsuitable for life, such as deserts, a skill check is needed to succeed at this action. Failure indicates that the time is wasted.

item.title: Butcher
item.description:
Spend a minute to use Survival to skin, drain, dress, and otherwise harvest the organic components from a recently killed creature.
Obtaining organic loot from creatures is an important part of the game. Creatures that have listed drops when butchered will always give these items without a check if there is not a listed DC. Any organic materials that reasonably spoil will do so if not used in a timely manner (varies based off the part, but no less than 3 days).
Using Survival to get additional resources beyond what is listed in a creature's entry grants materials worth an amount equal to the creature's LV^2 times 10. This has a DC of 10+creature's LV. At the DM's discretion, the harvest can be worth more or less or made easier or harder depending on the rarity of the creature and demand for its products.

item.title: Navigate
item.description: When moving through unfamiliar territory, Survival can be used to get a sense of direction and move towards an intended destination. Higher rolls include avoiding unwanted encounters, while lower rolls represent less progress made towards the destination, or reaching the incorrect destination.

item.title: Detect
item.description: As a Standard Action, you become more observant of your surroundings, gaining an additional Perception check to detect traps, creatures, or details that are hidden from view. When a creature is not doing anything with its Standard Action and is moving at a normal pace, it is assumed to be using Detect Hidden Presence every round.

item.title: Quiz
item.description: Use Profession to answer basic questions about a type of craft or service job. Most simple facts are DC 10, but anything higher is Trained-only. Proficient creatures automatically know most simple facts about their Profession.

item.title: Performance
item.description:
Attempt to put on a show for other creatures using Perform. Whether it's music, action, or stand-up, benefits will be extended to entertaining individuals.
Performances are an important part of every culture. They are a commonly desired luxury, and some Afflictions require Performance as a cure.

item.title: Difficulty and Integrity
item.description: The Equivocation of Optional Mechanics as Difficulty Management in Video GamesIn the ongoing conversation about difficulty in games, it is crucial to recognize the different ways designers shape challenge—whether through numeric adjustments, increased enemy complexity, or opt-in mechanics like summoning or assistive features. Unfortunately, many argue that all optional mechanics are neutral tools for difficulty management that do not impact the core gameplay experience. As players and developers, we should focus on creating environments that allow individuals to experience the game in the way they prefer—including doing so without imposing significant changes that undermine the integrity of the core challenge. The goal should be to empower players while respecting both the game’s design and their personal approach to difficulty.In the gaming landscape, the design of difficulty and balance is a necessary part of accessibility for users with handicaps - especially in harder titles. Players that are too old or too new, that have responsibilities that pull them from the game, limited time, or that simply lack the necessary abilities to enjoy a game should have the necessary means to level the playing field. The design of difficulty in games can be broadly categorized into three distinct approaches: numeric, complexity-based, and opt-in mechanics. Numeric difficulty involves straightforward adjustments such as increasing enemy health, damage output, or resource scarcity, making encounters more difficult through quantifiable means. This is the most simple approach, and is used as part of the other approaches - but alone is often only appropriate for games with minimalist mechanics and low skill expression. Complexity-based difficulty, on the other hand, will change enemies to act with more intelligence, have more varied abilities and attack patterns, and require players to master the mechanics already present in the game to keep up. This is often the preferred method for any game with strategy or skill expression, but is the most taxing to implement. Finally, opt-in mechanics—such as summoning allies, flying, or activating other assistive features—allow players to choose whether to bypass or mitigate certain challenges altogether. While these mechanics are often presented as optional tools for difficulty management, their adoption and integration can fundamentally alter the player’s experience. There's a clear outlier here. There are no limits to what developers can put into their games as "optional" mechanics. The flexibility is a double-edged sword, as the implementation can just as easily ruin the experience if there is not an appropriate alternative or less invasive means. For the purposes of this discussion, I will mainly refer to Skyrim, Mario, and Elden Ring.All three methods of designing difficulty can easily interrupt the core gameplay experience when implemented thoughtlessly. In Skyrim, there is very little strategy and skill expression. At best, the player can move out of the range of some enemy attacks and strike back between them, or properly aim an arrow. Beyond that, the game is no different to MMOs such as RuneScape, where the player either engages in a slap fight whose winner is determined entirely by opposing statistics and how much healing is in their inventories, or the player stands out of reach of a melee opponent and attacks them with ranged weapons until they die helplessly. Skyrim uses numeric difficulty. Despite being the easiest approach, there are major oversights in its implementation that force players to use specific playstyles or exploits to keep up. For example, a player that wants to use primarily destruction magic will be greatly disappointed on higher difficulties as their entire Magicka bar is depleted defeating a single lesser bandit, and the abysmal regeneration rate and lack of potions will force them to resort to sword fighting or the use of AI exploits and loading zones. As the game progresses, the only way to have enough Magicka to defeat enemies without hours of grinding is through Alchemy-Enchanting exploits that bring the cost of spells to 0, or their damage to arbitrarily high numbers—the latter of which completely defeats the purpose of the numeric difficulty increase.Complexity-based difficulty is the hardest to implement. With the exception of complexity through AI improvements, it requires making more content on top of what should already be an adequate amount of content for lower difficulties. The more mechanics an enemy has, the higher the odds that they will invalidate a certain method of playing the game and require players to do something they are not interested in. For example, if the difficulty is in higher enemy aggression, then any playstyle that relies on large openings is going to suffer disproportionately. If the difficulty is in close-range incapacitation, then melee players will suffer more than ranged ones. Sacrificing some part of the original experience is often inevitable. There are exceptions where the numeric and complexity approaches meet. The speed of a game and the precision of its timings are a good example—Most of the game remains untouched, and a small adjustment in the reaction time necessary to beat the game can be the difficulty a player wants.At the crux of the issue lies difficulty through optional mechanics. These are the most likely to change the experience of a player. In Elden Ring, the variety of abilities in the game ranges from completely impractical to game-trivializing superpowers. Some are very similar to each other, such as two weapons of the same class with similar movesets that have wildly different performance. Most are not at all similar, making the experience when switching from one to the next completely different. Despite this, one could make an argument that the difficulty in the game rises from which strategies the player chooses. The most polarizing optional mechanic is Summoning. This changes the game from single player to Co-Op vs AI, or Co-Op and AI vs AI. Using this, a player can use NPC assistants to make enemies ignore the player, or simply ask a friend to beat the game for them while they watch. The extreme nature of this mechanic has caused heated debate in online communities as to what extent an optional mechanic can be used to manage difficulty before it simply becomes thinly veiled cheating.Cheating in most games is simply breaking the rules to your benefit. In the context of early video games, cheating was specifically programmed into games using "cheat codes" that would allow players to break the rules. Later, specialized pieces of hardware such as Action Replay were introduced that are akin to modern hex editors, allowing players to cheat by changing any variable they could find, far beyond what developers willingly included in their games. All of these were widely agreed to be forms of cheating. And yet, the definition of cheating became more flexible as time passed, even though little changed in what players were capable of.In Super Mario games, there exist powerups that grant the player complete invincibility combined with another powerup that only appear when a player has died in a level multiple times. These are essentially easily accessible god modes that can be used to skip content that is too difficult or boring to play normally, or for any other reason the players see fit. There is no code that needs to be input. There is no need to go out of one's way to obtain these powerups. They aren't even labeled as cheats. They are even included with explicit intent to be used by a portion of the player base—while many cheats in the past were added just for the sake of having cheats (such as with Big Head Mode) or as rewards for completing the game. And yet, despite the lack of labeling, there is a subtle acknowledgement that using these is different than beating the game "normally." Achievements and collectibles will look different, scores may be altered, and the game otherwise records your use of these items to give your completion of the game an asterisk.The difference between invincibility powerups and other cheats is that invincibility powerups are deliberate additions intended to help players of lower skill or patience complete the game. They are easy, low-effort inclusions that sacrifice a portion of the gameplay for an easier experience, which would sour the experience for players that do not need them. They are still, however, cheats. They break the rules to your benefit.In Skyrim (PC), the player can, at any time, open the console to manipulate the game via console commands. This is more akin to classic cheat codes, where no player would be able to guess what they need to type into the console to cause a specific effect without looking up the codes, but is closer to the power of hex editors in terms of possibilities. Skyrim's console blurs the concept of cheating far more than a handicap feature would. Unlike other cheat codes, the use of the console is far more common even among players that do not like cheats for one reason: Skyrim does not function as a game. Did the player get stuck in random map geometry? The console allows them to teleport out. Did a quest break? The console can skip to the next step. Did the game crash? The console can be used to restore progress without needing to replay content.By definition, these are all instances of cheating, yet many would decline to call it such. Cheating has a harsh connotation that someone is cheapening an experience by breaking the rules, and yet this time the cheats are used specifically to improve the experience of a broken game—and arguably play closer to the rules as intended.How do you know what a developer's intentions are? Intuition is a helpful tool, but it is also often wrong. Unless someone spoke their intentions, there cannot be certainty... But we can still make reasonably educated guesses.In Elden Ring, a common argument in favor of using anything the game offers is that, if it's in the game, it's intended to be used. The developers wouldn't have added it if they didn't intend for players to use it. This is obviously a baseless assertion, and there are plenty of examples where this intuitive reasoning falls short. Soon after the game's release, there were debates as to whether or not weapons such as Rivers of Blood and summons such as Mimic Tear were so powerful as to be unintended, or even be considered cheating. Players that defended these inclusions used the above argument, only to later find that both of these (and some underlying systems that improved them) were patched to reduce their effectiveness. Which one was truly the intended way of playing the game? Was it before or after the developers changed it? What else will the developers change? Can developers change their intentions? Some players that use this argument will make exceptions. For example, some enemies can be coerced into falling off of the map to their deaths, or get stuck such that they are easy targets. These will be exception cases, because their intuition tells them that the developers did not intend for enemies to simply fall off of the map and die on their own. And yet, despite the developers being able to modify the game however they wish, patches keep going by where these supposedly unintended inclusions remain untouched. When observing the design of the game, it is reasonable to try and guess developer intentions based on conflicting design principles and a charitable interpretation of the intelligence of whoever made it, even without the say of the developers. If in the vast majority of cases a condition is true, except for one specific case where there does not seem to be any reason for the deviation, an argument can be made that the aberration is not intended. For example, in Elden Ring, there are almost always methods to avoid an instance of damage as a player of reasonable reaction time and positioning. Enemy attack patterns will place the attacks in such a way that that is always the case for their target. However, if there are multiple enemies, an attack may be placed in such a way that it is avoidable for the primary target, but not for any others nearby. This can be considered an unintentional side effect of the optional mechanic of multiplayer.In Minecraft (Java Edition), players frequently modify the game using third party programs to drastically alter the gaming experience in ways far outside of the scope of the original game. It would be reasonable to assume that the intentions of the developer do not take into account anything a player may find in the landscape of unofficial changes to the game. Some of these modifications may be considered cheating, while most are considered changing the game entirely such that it is no longer "truly" Minecraft. However, there are modifications to the game whose only purpose is to improve the performance of the game, allowing more players the ability to play the game at all. Some modifications fix behaviors and perceived oversights to make the game more consistent.Are these third party changes bringing the experience closer to what was intended? The Minecraft speed-running community certainly thinks that some do. Performance-boosting modifications that do not change the basic rules of the game are allowed and encouraged. It's intuitive that the game running better rather than worse is the intention of the developers. Being able to reset the game more quickly or load faster are generally accepted to not be considered in the realm of cheating due to not affecting the integrity of the performance of the player during their speed-run.There it is—Integrity. There is a sort of principled superiority that cheating is playing the game "wrong," and that accomplishments that were only acquired via cheating are illegitimate. This intuitive understanding is highly attractive, as speaking with someone who claims the same accomplishments as yourself while having a different experience reaching that goal will inevitably cause a disconnect. It can invoke feelings of mockery, as if your efforts are being undermined and cheapened by someone with a GameShark. Cheaters that are perceived to lack integrity are seen as dishonest and insincere.It is no surprise that people will be on the lookout for any examples of something that can be seen as cheating. Whenever there are perceived rules and the perceived breaking of said rules, there will be conflict among players. Developers should keep this aspect of human nature in mind when designing their game, especially if they do not put any effort into explaining their intentions to the players. Players are less inclined to fuss about cheating and accomplishments when difficulty and handicaps are properly communicated to them. When numeric and complexity difficulties are clearly labeled "Easy," "Medium," and "Hard" with descriptions of their effects, and opt-in mechanics are properly balanced or labeled as handicaps, players are more likely to be able to have civil discussions about the game's design.At the end of the day, the purpose of games is to have fun. Players will act in accordance with what they find most enjoyable (and accessible), and they will associate with other players that have similar values to their own. Players are also not expected to have the emotional intelligence or logic capacity to put together well-reasoned and compassionate arguments to connect with others that do not think like them. They are expected to complain, pick sides, and attack anyone with opposing views, needlessly causing divides that the developers could have easily avoided.Elden Ring is a gold mine of thoughtless arguments and assumptions from players due to the vague and often half-baked implementation of its core difficulty management mechanics. For this, we will be focusing on the debate around the users of summons against solo/difficulty purists, as both sides suffer from astounding levels of shortsightedness on the subject.Let's start with solo purists that claim that anyone that used summons did not truly "beat the game" and that they "played the game wrong." There are legitimate arguments to be made about the poor implementation and incredible variance in effectiveness from the use of summons. Truly, they can be akin to using a Super Leaf in Mario games to skip entire areas and bosses from the sheer power that having another player or ally in a fight can bring. The way enemies do not take into account the presence of additional enemies for their choice of actions reveals a lack of polish or worse. In some cases, enemy AI will simply cease to function when a creature is defeated, or their movements and bodies will become unnatural as they change targets mid-attack, resulting in deceptive and jarring visuals that do not appear as intended behavior. However, there is no reason to attack others for choices made for the purposes of entertainment in what may as well be a single-player game. Without the developers defining what it means to beat the game, like in Mario, the player's assertions are baseless.As the player progresses further into the game, many of the enemies have identical gameplay with only minor cosmetic differences—and enormously increased statistics. It is not uncommon for a player to fight a generic soldier with a sword and trade hits to defeat them in one blow, only to find the exact same enemy wearing a different color shirt that can kill the player in a single blow. It is entirely possible for a player to simply not have enough ammunition to defeat even a single enemy from differences in numeric difficulty, resulting in certain playstyles being invalidated via arithmetic impossibility. What would normally be a method of difficulty control instead becomes a burden for the player to level up their character to unreasonable strength, skewing the experience unnecessarily because of arbitrary restrictions from the developers. Furthermore, the action of increasing one's level has no relation to the core gameplay experience or player skill. If a player wishes to improve their numerical abilities until winning is possible, they will most likely resort to repeatedly resting at a save point and attacking defenseless enemies for an arbitrary amount of time until they have enough points to do so. There is no option to use skill to increase one's ability to deal damage when the resources used to do so are limited - if you have ten shots, and the enemy can survive eleven, no amount of skill will help you win. The increase in "difficulty" using numbers serves no purpose except to waste hours of a player's time when players opt for weaker strategies.Strategies and weapons that are stronger or weaker are often touted as the game's main way of adjusting difficulty. In many cases, these are legitimate, non-invasive methods that do not significantly alter the core gameplay experience. If a player likes a specific kind of weapon or spell, chances are there are alternatives that function similarly enough while being substantially more or less effective. It's always easier to reduce effectiveness, as a player can choose not to upgrade a weapon, but it is not always possible to increase the strength of a playstyle past a certain point. That is the point at which this method of difficulty implementation fails. It is a common argument among users of summons that anyone that complains about numeric difficulty while refusing to use opt-in playstyles is trapped in a cage of their own making. This view isn't just false, it's patronizing and misses the valid portion of the purist argument. Summoning, for example, changes the core experience of the game to such a degree that it can and will lead to questions of integrity and legitimacy in a run. Even inexperienced players identify that someone or something else defeating enemies for them "feels" like it made their own contributions irrelevant (because it did).That all tools the game offers are equally valid means of managing difficulty is an equivocation. To insist others use them in the same way they would an "enemy health and damage multiplier" lacks nuance and borders on dishonesty. To the purists, telling them to "just summon" is no different than telling them to "just play Tetris instead," "just use the Super Leaf," or "have you considered handing the controller to your big brother?" since, to them, it is either an alternative game experience that doesn't interest them, or actively cheapens the experience of the game akin to cheating, even if the developers did not say such. To them, the game simply lacks the means to make their chosen way of playing the right difficulty, and their way of playing the game for entertainment is just as valid as the summoners.This problem also exists in reverse. For example, what if someone wants to play with their friends, but does not want to make the game too easy? There are numeric ways to make yourself weaker, but the core experience is warped. No amount of self-restriction will make up for the fact that enemies in the game are not designed to act differently in the presence of multiple opponents.There is one last drawback of opt-in mechanics as difficulty, especially in Elden Ring: Not all mechanics are even available from the start. If you want to play the game from start to finish with Godfrey's Axe, you are required to either arrange for another player to drop the item for you, or you need to cheat. That's right: there are playstyles that are not even accessible. The game does not have a reasonable method to enjoy items granted only after beating the game. This is not even for balance reasons either, as items like Fire Giant's braid and Godfrey's Axe are incredibly weak weapons compared to similar ones obtainable earlier in the game. Limited items exist that never respawn or force players to waste time collecting rare resources, which needlessly punishes inexperienced or challenge run players that are more likely to fail when using them. Given everything discussed, using cheats for the purposes of enabling the game to be played in a specific way that does not affect the integrity of the core gameplay is something that should be reasonable to most. The issue is not cheating, it's integrity. There should always be methods of controlling difficulty within a given set of rules while respecting those rules, self-imposed or otherwise. If the developers fail to do so, it is perfectly within reason for players to point it out.

item.title: Potency
item.description:
Potency is the default DC of abilities used by a creature.
This is usually 10+LV+LUK.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Potency.md

item.title: Offense Calculator
item.description: Hit Chance = 19.09% Attack Power = 22 Target's Defense Power = 638.8 Time to Kill = 29.04 RoundsThis Time to Kill formula is not accurate for Hit Chances above 100%.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Offense Calculator.md

item.title: Example DCs
item.description: Common modifiers to make the task more difficult can include racism, your questions/requests being offensive or closely guarded secrets by the target, and not being well-liked by the person/people you are persuading.Common modifiers to make the task less difficult can include being well-liked by the person/people you are persuading, holding a position of authority over them, or it would benefit the person you're speaking to to reveal the information you're looking for.

item.title: Gather Information
item.description: When in a settlement, you can use Persuasion to find the answer to a simple question by speaking to people in town. The time it takes and the difficulty scales with the size of the settlement, people's general attitude toward you, and how knowledgeable they are on the subject. Asking about where someone lives in a village could take minutes, but asking in a large city could take hours.

item.title: Invisible
item.description: You cannot be detected by sight. This grants you Total Concealment against any creature that primarily uses sight. You must still use Stealth to hide your presence and specific location, or else creatures will still be able to attack your space to try and hit you.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Invisible.md

item.title: Circumstance
item.description:
Circumstance is any in-game situation, event, or position that conditionally applies a bonus, penalty, or Status to a creature.
Circumstances can apply to different creatures in different ways, usually based on positioning or the presence or absence of abilities - for example, having a low wall to grant you Cover will work for any creatures on the other side of the wall, but not on the same side as you. One creature may see you while you're in a cloud, while another cannot. You may be above one creature, but another creature may be above you. Therefore, these effects are circumstantial.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Circumstance.md

item.title: Identify Affliction or Curse
item.description:
Use Trained Medicine to examine a creature for one minute. You can identify whether they have an Affliction or Curse, the effects of such, and how to cure them.
The DC is 5 times the Affliction level, or the DC of the Curse.

item.title: Prevent Recovery
item.description: Use Trained Medicine for one minute to prevent a Defeated creature from being able to recover on their own. This lasts 24 hours.

item.title: Long Term Care
item.description: Use Trained Medicine to assist yourself or another creature such that they can recover a stack of Drained every 3 days instead of 7. This care is required for some Afflictions.

item.title: Provide First Aid
item.description: Use Trained Medicine as a Standard Action to cure a creature in reach of Status ailments. You can remove Sickened stacks, Bleeding, and Blurred Vision. The DC of removing any of these conditions is the DC of the ability that inflicted them.

item.title: Assess Vitality
item.description: Using Medicine, you can examine a creature that is wounded to determine how they were injured, how long ago it happened, and whether they are in grave danger of dying. This also functions on corpses for cause of death. The more complex the ailment and the longer the duration since it happened, the higher the DC. Difficulty based on duration may reverse in scaling in the case of diseases, where more time passing makes the symptoms more obvious.

item.title: Language
item.description: Most creatures that can speak will know Common. Some isolated or xenophobic creatures may only speak their native tongue.

item.title: Take 30
item.description: When not under duress, you can spend ten times the time the task normally takes to achieve your best effort, automatically getting a Natural 30. It is assumed you trigger the failure result ten times, making this unsuitable for crafting or disarming traps.

item.title: Encode or Decode Documents
item.description: Using Linguistics, you can write things in ways that are difficult to interpret without a cipher, such as disguising your forbidden ritual as a cookbook. The DC to your code is 10+(Linguistics bonus). Creatures that know the code can read encoded text, but creatures that don't will interpret the text as something else. To read encoded text, you must first crack the code, usually requiring at least a week of research. At the end of the week, roll a Linguistics check versus the writer’s DC to crack the code.

item.title: Write or Forge Documents
item.description: Using Linguistics, you can make contracts, forge signatures, and make fake (or real) documents look official. Noticing oddities in such documents requires an opposed Linguistics check.

item.title: Interpret Text
item.description: Using Linguistics, you peruse a book, contract, or other written work to quickly summarize what it says in one minute. The DC for most works is 10, but it changes based on the size and complexity of the work at hand. Failure indicates more time is necessary to understand what the text contains. Finding oddities in a contract requires an opposed Linguistics check.

item.title: Entangled
item.description: Creature gets -2 AC, and their Speed is reduced to zero. This condition usually comes with a means to escape manually with Athletics. Creatures without the entangled condition receive a +5 bonus on checks to untangle a creature.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Entangled.md

item.title: Math and Worldbuilding
item.description: The Neglect of Mathematics and Game Balance in Tabletop Roleplaying GamesIn all forms of interactive storytelling where numbers are involved, the narratives and imaginations of those involved are grounded in and informed by the underlying mathematics and mechanics. Just like in the real world, math is the basis on which everything exists - change one variable, and the world and the cultures within will look much different. Despite this foundational importance, the math in TTRPGs is often neglected or not taken into consideration during its creation, causing the stories built on it to lack plausibility or the players to engage in degenerate gameplay loops that are better incentivized by the math. We must elevate the standards of game balance and mathematical principles within to ensure a stable play environment with maximal freedom of storytelling.For the purpose of this discussion, I'll mostly be referring to the design of Dungeons and Dragons, but these principles extend to all games, TTRPG or otherwise.Here in the real world, our actions are most often decided by their expected outcomes. People grow the food that produces the most in the local terrain, they wear protection to avoid death, they take the path of least resistance, they outlaw actions that harm others. If the outcomes or goals were different, the actions taken would be different - if stabbing someone was a pleasant experience that extended their lifespan, then the laws around stabbing people would be very different. If we only ate for pleasure, we would grow what tasted the best regardless of climate. This is true down to the very foundations of the universe, where the actions that the atoms and forces of the universe take are decided by simple rules. Light takes the path of least time, mass and energy act towards increased entropy, and other such rules determine how everything else acts.Just like in real life, expected outcomes are what guide us in TTRPGs. If the goal of the player is to live the longest and kill the most things, then the actions they take will be guided by what best gets them to that goal. Because this is based on probability, it becomes a question of simple math to determine the best course of action at a given moment. All else the same, the weapon that does the most damage should be what everybody in the world defaults to. All else the same, the strategy that prevents the most damage taken is the best. Math IS worldbuilding. In real life, we can't fight against monsters and men-at-arms with shuriken and our bare fists. Reality dictates that those actions would likely result in our demise. However, in a game, we often find ourselves roleplaying something that isn't exactly realistic - such as a magician slinging fireballs at ogres. If we want to allow the full range of themes to be represented in a game, we need all of them to be on a fair playing field. There is no purpose to allowing "Unarmed Strike" as an action that accomplishes nothing and gets you killed, after all - but we decide the rules of this universe. We can make "Unarmed Strike" deal substantial damage, or have additional benefits that make their use reasonable. By setting the rules properly, what is feasible changes to match our desires.Whether what you desire is a good thing is a discussion for another day - let's focus on the hows.What players do is a combination of what they desire, and what the game rewards. Developers should set the rules to reward what they want to happen, and not reward what they don't. Ideally, the incentives should match what the players want to do.The incentive structure of a game like DnD usually comes in the form of power. More money and experience means bigger and more magical swords and fireballs, or more hirelings, etcetera. When you want a fair game for players to enjoy various themes and strategies, you must balance the power such that there is not a single overwhelmingly dominant strategy that is easily recognized by players. This is only fair; if you have multiple players, and one is given obviously inferior power, they may experience frustration or disengagement when they notice their impact on the game is insubstantial as a result.Fairness in a system of mathematics is fundamentally a question of mathematics.When the underlying math is neglected, and the rest of the game is built despite it, you will quickly find oddities. If you make "Unarmed Strike" deal 1 damage, and "Longsword" deal between 1 and 8, you should not be surprised when nobody will opt for "Unarmed Strike" under any circumstances. If there is a dominant strategy, and yet you still declare that most of the people in this world fight with fists instead of swords (all else equal), your world becomes less believable. From the math, the rest of the world-building should come naturally and without significant leaps of logic - If you declare something exists in this world, there should be a basis for it, and this basis almost always comes from the math.Balanced systems inherently foster deeper engagement. Players are more likely to invest their time into the mechanics of a game when they believe they will not be held back by deviating from superior strategies. By employing mathematical approaches to skill scaling, damage output, resource allocation, and character progression, players are free to choose options based on thematics, creativity, and their own desires without worrying about doing the math on behalf of the developers to make sure they are being dealt a fair hand.Everything I've stated so far may seem obvious, and even patronizing, but the reality is that most developers do not take this into consideration as much as they should.I'll spare you the fine details and skip to the important math to keep in mind. In DnD, there are listed weapons that are assumed to be available from character creation. If we consider the world in which this takes place, it would be fair to assume that the people in the world would also want to survive encounters when selecting their weaponry, and those weapons are boiled down to sets of numbers and tags to describe them. The most important number to a commoner with no bonuses to anything is the damage number - in a fight, the odds to succeed are highest by simply using the weapon with the highest damage. And yet, a dagger deals 2.5 damage, while a stick deals 3.5. If they use a very big stick, they can even reach 4.5, if they don't mind using both hands. If they spend some more money and actions, they can use two axes for a whopping 7 damage, and this is only with "simple" weapons they may be proficient in.The simple conclusion here is that, all else equal, a commoner's preferred weapon should be a stick, or two axes if they have money to spare. The stick is the most versatile, cheap, and powerful weapon available to them. Even if you take into account the bonuses from stats, a commoner would need maximum dexterity to consider a dagger, even compared to weapons they are not proficient in. In this world, using a dagger is mathematically inferior to every other option for any regular, non-player character. This results in a silly world that only suits the players, without taking into account the rest of the creatures. Why would a knife be a substantially worse weapon than a stick? A goat that attacks a human is likely to kill them in a single attack. How long would a farmer last in such a world?Some classes and builds can easily survive far longer and deal multiple times as much damage as others, often while being better at non-combat activities as well. Why would anyone willingly choose to be the inferior class if the objective is to survive? The expected earnings of a player far outpace the earnings of commoners, as untrained labor is only enough to pay for a gallon of ale or a stay at a poor inn while a single piece of basic equipment can be worth a hundred times as much. Is it really acceptable to put the price on a day of deadly work (such as a mercenary) equal to the price of a dagger, one of the worst items in the game, such that a player could hire dozens of them for every adventure?How long can you ride on a player's goodwill and desire for thematics and roleplay before these poor worldbuilding decisions start to interfere with their fantasy?One of the most insidious phenomena in the world of TTRPGs is the tendency of players to defend poor mathematics and imbalanced mechanics, often born out of a fundamental misunderstanding or intentional ignorance of underlying principles. This defense frequently stems from a place of trust in the developers and an emotional attachment to the game itself, leading players to uphold the perceived authority of the creators."If they wanted it that way, they would have made it that way!""You think they didn't think of that? They clearly left it like that for a reason." "Why don't you do better, then?"When players encounter a system that is hailed as "official," there is a natural inclination to assume that the developers have meticulously crafted every detail, and thus, their choices are unquestionable. Players may erroneously believe that since the developers designed the game, they must have considered every possible variable and outcome, rendering any criticism unwarranted. Players may also propagate the myth of developer infallibility, asserting that they are privy to unique insights that justify design decisions. Such attitudes not only inhibit constructive discourse, but they also diminish the validity of collective player experiences and insights, as an entire community’s lived experiences may be rendered irrelevant in the face of perceived expertise. The belief that there "can’t be a better way" is a common claim that started among video game developers, such as at Riot Games and Nexon, as they frequently cite data they claim exists to justify their actions while refusing to release said data to prove it. The truth is that no such data exists, and modern gaming communities can easily get access to or create superior data from which to make decisions.When confronted with suggestions for rebalance, players often leap to the defense of their cherished mechanics, positing that the developers "must have had a reason" for their choices. This blind and aggressive defense of the systems further perpetuates the cycle of flawed designs, as those advocating for improvement or merely offering their observations are dismissed as "Powergamers," or told that they're just not focusing on what matters, and that roleplay trumps game design.Because the foundation of these defenses is inherently fallacious, they almost always lead to a statement that reveals their lack of engagement with the topic. The most common ones include that the game is made to be changed from table to table, that the suggestions are merely opinions and do not represent the needs of the community, that the opinions of those that are not part of successful gaming companies are inherently worthless, and basic attacks on the character of those criticizing the game (rather than focusing on the criticisms themselves).Most players lack the mathematical literacy necessary to fully grasp the implications of game mechanics at a detailed level. Consequently, when flaws in balance emerge—be they overpowered abilities, inefficient resource distribution, or underwhelming options—players may misinterpret these issues as subjective preferences rather than objective mathematical failings. The most common misinterpretation of the math is that of percentage reductions: Most players do not know that reducing an effect by 100% is far more than twice as good as reducing it by 50%. A common way this ignorance appears is in video games such as League of Legends, Minecraft, and Skyrim, where players will honestly believe that combining a reduction of 50% with another 50% and getting a result of 75% is somehow a "diminished" effect because the total did not reach 100%, when in reality the result is a multiplicative, mathematically accurate, and fair way to represent the effect.Combined with the aforementioned bias towards that which is "official," a majority of the population will convince themselves that their intuitive (incorrect) understanding of the underlying mathematics is also aligned with what the developers think - and, unfortunately, they may be correct.The methods used by the developers of DnD to create the game and the underlying math is transparently dubious. By their own (unwitting) admission, the top-down approaches used by them with a lack of emphasis on mechanics and math, insufficient player testing, and dismissal of community feedback has led to books full of wondrous descriptions of a game that does not accurately match their vision in practice.The examples of such are too numerous to list, but to bring up simultaneous examples that perfectly encapsulate the sheer nescience of the lead developers of DnD, we can look at the playtests of DnD 5.5. During the playtests, the developers made a particularly bizarre public video about the results, falsely claiming that a mechanic that players did not interact with was "mathematically one of the most powerful" when it was the worst on average, dismissing feedback because player scores on individual features were higher than the overall score, and even incorrectly referencing their own changes to their own content. What truly happened behind the scenes to cause such a public statement to be made without any proofreading is unclear. It's up to a given individual to review these actions to decide whether it's negligence, ignorance, or deliberate equivocation. I try taking the most charitable approach by assigning ignorance to what could have just as easily been malice.Game developers must adopt a mathematical mindset in their approach. This includes rigorous playtesting with statistical analyses, iterative balancing, and a commitment to utilizing clear metrics for evaluating the effectiveness and fairness of mechanics while maintaining consistency and logic. Checking published content for faults should not be the burden of the players, especially when the product is advertised as being beginner-friendly. Disparities that can be encountered within a new player's first turn should not be tolerated, let alone upheld as intended design.Players should be involved in the balancing process, and even perceived faults in criticism should be thoroughly investigated to identify the underlying reasons for the criticisms being put forth. When a community is particularly large, there's a high likelihood that there will be individuals that practically design the game in its entirety in their criticisms. To dismiss them is the peak of hubris. When a game's fundamentals and mathematical foundations are made airtight, the content built on them will likewise be untouchable. Under ideal circumstances, even inexperienced players should be able to expand on the content in the game with little worry of diminishing the balance. I hope to one day live in a world where criticisms of game balance and mathematics are truly in the realm of the nitpicking and biased, and that all game discussion becomes that of themes and abstractions.

item.title: History
item.description: All Knowledge Skills can be used to glean relevant History for their subject matters. The includes recalling major events, figures, artifacts, and deciphering hieroglyphs.

item.title: Divine Lore
item.description: Using Religion, you can identify a symbol (DC 10) tied to a person, object, or locale to determine its religious affiliation, as well as the tenets (DC 15) of a given religion and its chosen (DC 20) artifacts, people, and events of significance. You can also determine how to gain favor from a particular god (DC 15).

item.title: Detect Portal
item.description:
Using Planes, you can detect, identify, and disable portals.
Portals are strange phenomenon, but there are signs that they exist miles away from where the portal is actually located. If a portal is naturally occurring, you can use a DC 30 check to find its general area, or where it appears if it is not currently open. If it's manufactured, you can use a DC 20 check, or the caster's opposed Arcana, whichever is higher.In the presence of a portal, you can tell where its destination plane is. Rolling higher can give more specific locations, more details about the portals creation and how often it gets used. This starts at DC 10.Disabling a portal is a task that is very difficult by one's self. Failure could mean getting stuck on the wrong side of the portal, or hyper-charging the portal to attract extraplanar creatures. Using Planes is usually a short-term and rushed method. The DC starts at 30.
Using a Ritual with Invocation and Arcana can make the process of disabling a portal more safe.

item.title: Identify Natural Phenomenon
item.description: Use Nature to identify natural processes like photosynthesis, the reproduction of creatures, and tectonic activity. You can do things like figuring out if a volcano is about to erupt, what could be causing plants to die, or how long until an egg hatches. You can also identify natural fauna, flora, and minerals, and their potential uses.When used to predict weather, you need to roll well to accurately predict more than a day ahead. You can also tell whether the weather is natural, or if it's being caused by magic.

item.title: Identify Structural Quirk
item.description: Large scale buildings such as castles, watchtowers, walls, factories, prisons etc. Are all built with specific purposes, facilities and defenses in mind. You can use Engineering to figure out aspects of these buildings, such as where exhaust/waste pipes lead, how far underground you might need to go to go underneath the structure, and even structural weaknesses.

item.title: Hack
item.description: Using Engineering, where there exists technology, there exists a method to disable or gain control of it, even if only temporarily. Hacking always requires a hands-on approach.

item.title: Identify Cosmic Phenomenon
item.description: Using Astronomy with aid of devices such as telescopes (if necessary), you can determine the cause of cosmic phenomenon, or you can predict them in advance. This can be something like a solar eclipse, a comet, or something more drastic like a meteor or supernova.You can also tell if something unusual is happening, such as someone using illusions to improperly represent the night sky, or cast spells that produce effects similar to cosmic phenomenon.

item.title: Identify Function
item.description: Use Engineering to identify the purpose of particularly complex machinery. Depending on the size and scope of what you're looking at, this could only be a glance, or it could require a few minutes, and usually requires a hands-on approach.

item.title: Navigation
item.description: With a clear view of the night time sky, you can determine where you are and where you need to be. You can use Astronomy as an alternative to Survival for navigation in such circumstances. This skill replaces Survival during space travel.

item.title: CC
item.description: A Debilitating Status (CC) is one that impedes your movement or prevents you from taking actions normally.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/CC.md

item.title: Speed
item.description: Default ground movement speed is 30. Race, Class, Equipment, and Status can change this. Some actions grant extra speed.You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Speed.md

item.title: AS
item.description:
Attack Speed (AS): In order to decide how many attacks to make, you must use the AS of anything available to you when you take your Attack Action. Most weapons have an AS greater than 1, allowing you to make multiple attacks. If you have multiple ways to attack, you can combine them together. However, you cannot "overlap" your AS. To visualize this -

Here we have a character that has a dagger in hand with an AS of 5, a mace in the other with an AS of 3, and multiple Action-Attacks with an AS of 1. He can take one action from every column, meaning if you use a Spell (AS-1) you can no longer do any attacks that use the same column. He could do 5 dagger attacks 4 dagger attacks and a Spell a Special Attack and 2 mace attacks and 2 dagger attacks, etc... However, he cannot do a Spell and a Special Attack on the same turn, as they only have an AS of 1 individually.

item.title: Dual Wielding
item.description: When using something in each hand, you gain the full benefits of both. You may benefit from two staves granting casting bonuses, use both of their AS, a sword and shield - whatever you like. If you use two weapons of the same AS, they gain +1 AS. Both weapons must be used at least once. You cannot engage in Dual-Wielding if you have a Two-Handed item. For example, you cannot swing a greatsword and then use Unarmed Strikes or throw shuriken with their higher AS.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Dual Wielding.md

item.title: Identify Composition
item.description: Use Alchemy on an unknown substance to learn how to create it, if it has or can be created through Alchemy. The DC is the Craft DC+5.

item.title: Free Action
item.description:
Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason. See: Delay
Swap Item
Monster Lore
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Free Action.md

item.title: Intuition
item.description:
By using Trained Insight, you can observe a structure or item whose function is known, an event unfolding, or a behavior pattern to try and glean information about it. The DC is modified by how much knowledge you already possess on the topic, or how closely you're able to investigate it. A success gives you nearly prescient knowledge about the intention behind the structure, item, event, or behavioral pattern that goes beyond a basic understanding of function.
For example, when used on a Trap whose function is to shoot an arrow, your character may determine that based on its unusual angle and obvious placement, it may have been used to deter adventures from finding a secret in its line of sight instead of to actually effectively trap them. The knowledge you glean from this success will always be the reality of the situation when you follow your intuition.

item.title: Disguise
item.description: Using Trained Deception, spend 10 minutes perfecting your makeup, outfit, and wig to appear as a person or playable race you're not. Disguise checks are usually unnecessary unless you fall under scrutiny, the person knows you/what you're pretending to be, or you're trying to enter an exclusive club, in which case they get a Perception check. Creatures get bonuses to their Perception if they know you or what you're disguised as particularly well.You take a -2 penalty to Disguise when you try to change your race and when you change your apparent gender. When you initiate a Disguise, you tell your DM your bonus, they apply any appropriate Circumstance modifiers and roll it in secret.Crafting a disguise without a disguise kit or magic imposes a -5 penalty.

item.title: Detect Compulsion
item.description: Use Trained Insight to determine when a creature is under duress from a spell or some other kind of effect that has a lasting impact on their mind, such as when Dominated or Possessed. You must actively search for this by speaking with the creature for 1 minute. Roll Insight vs the DC of the effect. If the effect has no DC, assume a basic DC based on the Potency of the source.

item.title: Coercion
item.description:
With Trained Intimidation, by having a conversation with a creature that lasts at least one minute, or by defeating a creature in combat, you can shape how they respond to you or anybody asking about you in the future. The strength of this creature's conviction is dependent on your Intimidation Roll against it.
You can make the creature keep their mouth shut about something you did to them. Any checks to gather information from this creature about you or your party change to your roll if it would be higher than the usual DC.
You can greatly exaggerate what you did to further spread fear and grand tales of your strength. Any Knowledge checks that creatures make on you when hearing about information that spreads from this creature changes to your Intimidation roll if it would be higher than the usual DC, or else they learn false information.

item.title: Demoralize
item.description:
As an Action-Attack, inflict Shaken 1 on an enemy that can see or hear you within 30 feet. Roll Intimidation versus their Will. They are Shaken as long as you are nearby, and for 1 minute after. You can Demoralize a creature repeatedly to increase the penalty. If they pass their save, their shaken value from Demoralize decreases by 1.
If you are Trained, you can inflict Frightened instead on creatures you have Defeated before. This lasts one round, and can only be done once per day per creature. This doesn't work if they Defeated you once before as well.

item.title: Subtle Message
item.description: By speaking in roundabout terms and making subtle gestures, you can use Trained Deception to communicate a simple idea (such as "we need to leave", or "time to strike") while not talking about it directly, to avoid alerting others of your intentions. The DC to convey this message is 20. The intended recipient automatically understands the message. Anyone that may be suspicious gets an Insight check to beat your Deception.

item.title: Tie
item.description: When making an opposed Skill check, ties are rerolled.

item.title: Create a Distraction
item.description: Using Deception as a Standard Action, you can shout something at your enemies to briefly get them to look the other way so you can give them the slip. All creatures get a roll to try and beat yours. If you succeed, you are able to roll Stealth, and they won't know where you went. This does not prevent people from finding you again using Perception.

item.title: Submerged
item.description: Target is completely surrounded in liquid. This triggers Aquatic Combat and Improved Cover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Submerged.md

item.title: Prone
item.description: Creature is lying down or otherwise on the ground, has -4 AC and ACC, and can't move unless they spend 30 movement to end the condition, which Provokes.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Prone.md

item.title: Group Checks
item.description: When working cooperatively, such as to Craft an item or work a machine, use the group's highest bonus, plus 1 per helper, or 2 if they're also Proficient (max +10). When the weakest link can sink a team's effort, such as with Stealth, use the group's lowest bonus, plus the help.

item.title: Take 10
item.description: You can take 10 on non-opposed skill checks. This means instead of rolling, you automatically get a Natural 10. This is suitable for crafting or skipping tasks that aren't too difficult for you.

item.title: Proficiency
item.description: Proficiency in a Skill marks you as "Trained" rather than "Untrained." Proficiency grants more uses for some skills.

item.title: Critical Pet
item.description: Achievement Requirement - Use stealth to initiate combat on a creature by patting its head 3 times. This pat can have no mechanical effect such as delivering a spell or attacking.Reward - You unlock the "Pet" skill. It uses your stealth bonus. If you sneak up on a creature and pet their head (again, no additional mechanical effect), you establish dominance, giving you a +2 bonus to skills for the subsequent social or combat encounter. If a creature within reach is smaller than you, you can pet them as a free action 1/turn for no mechanical benefit (no save).

item.title: Battle Scars
item.description: Achievement Requirement - Get defeated by a critical hit and survive in 3 different encounters. Or get crit 3 times in the same combat and survive.Reward - The scars you get from battle are deeply entrenched in your memory. Your memories of combats you have encountered cannot be magically removed. By touching them, you can perfectly recall past events, as long as they happened in the thick of combat.
